This proposal will shape the future of Bloomfield Hills Schools. From the two preschool locations to the grade reconfiguration and middle school consolidation, this proposal considers our immediate and long-term needs.

The plan utilizes the best of what is available in our current infrastructure, preserving the community's previous investment and ensuring we are only asking voters for improvements that are absolutely necessary.

The E.L. Johnson Nature Center on Franklin Road, just south of Hickory Grove, was dedicated and named after retiring BHS Superintendent Eugene L. Johnson in 1970. It has an interpretive center, pond, maple sugar shack, miles of walking trails, and some friendly critters including deer and a hawk which have been injured and can't go back into the wild. post_text: Mid-day today, June 24, 2020, we were made aware of a compromised student email account. We appreciate the family notifying the district immediately so we could quickly begin an investigation into the issue. That investigation is still ongoing, but early findings suggest the incident is limited to this particular student’s account and was likely a device intrusion and not a vulnerability within the district’s system. If this holds true through the remainder of the investigation, it means no other accounts were compromised on our system. At this time, our IT team is not observing any abnormal behavior or receiving alerts to suggest any components of the BHS or Google system have been compromised. We are still looking into the facts of this situation and will continue to update the community if we learn more, but want to again emphasize that we do not believe any other account holders have reason to be concerned.

The Bloomfield Hills Schools Foundation provided a lot of summer smiles by coordinating and purchasing 6,000 Beyond Juice smoothie coupons for BHS students. The coupons are being handed out by various BHS schools either with summer packets or at locker and last day pick ups. In addition, the BHS Foundation was key to supporting summer learning by providing funding for summer learning experiences. With this resource, BHS has been able to purchase a Summer Bridges learning booklet for each of our K-7th grade students and also will be providing a BHS-created summer writing program packet for all students. "We appreciated the opportunity to support the district with a grant for the smoothies and the summer packets," said BHSF Executive Director Cathie Badalamenti.

Learn more: http://ow.ly/cz3T50A6fyr

This course meets the requirements of a 4th year math-related course or can count toward an engineering elective. #FeatureFriday

Nature Center News: Every year, our 4th graders help us conduct a bird census during the month of May, which includes capturing and banding song birds. This year, with the stay-at-home order still in place, we were able to conduct the census with a few staff!

Staff were then able to send our 4th grade teachers video lessons for their students to use at home. Highlights of this years' census included seeing a Bald Eagle on two different days and an Osprey gliding over our pond. Both of these birds were nearly extinct when our Nature Center first opened in 1970. #TidbitTuesday #BHSTogether

The great deal of concern about shortages of personal protective equipment (PPE) for medical staff prompted this family team, Blair McKendrick and West Hills student Thomas Chen, to spring into action. They use 3-D printers from Blair’s business to make headbands for medical shields and then attach projector sheets.

“We have already donated over 200 shields to St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Pontiac. Our biggest challenge is acquiring the projector sheets. We’ve looked everywhere online and all stores are out of stock”, explains Blair.

Thomas adds, “We are so appreciative of the sacrifice and risk medical staff make every day! We want to do whatever is in our control to help keep them safer.”

Bloomfield Hills Schools Speech and Language Pathologist Amy Goodwin shares: "Speech-Language Pathology is not limited to the remediation of speech sounds, or 'articulation.' It is so much more!"

Speech-Language Pathologists (SLP's) work with students who require assistance with their speech fluency (stuttering), language development (understanding and use of language) or social-pragmatic skills (the rules that govern social interaction).

In BHS, there are eleven SLP's who work with students in the general population, Wing Lake and Deaf/Hard of Hearing Program (DHH)." Thank a BHS SLP this month!

BHHS 10th grade students, Noah Roslin and Noah Yaker, recognized the best way to cope through this crisis is to help others. Co-creators of Big Buddies of Bloomfield, the program pairs high school students with elementary students, to spend time virtually whether it be tutoring school subjects or playing games.

Yaker and Roslin explain the goal of Big Buddies of Bloomfield, “We want to create a sense of community and connection between generations of students.High schoolers are also experiencing a sense of loss and loneliness, and many are looking for a way to help their community.”

The services offered are free of charge, although a voluntary donation of up to $10.00 per hour will be donated to the United Way for Southeastern Michigan COVID-19 community fund, which assists the most vulnerable in our community who have been impacted by the COVID-19 crisis.

For more information and to view the high school buddy bios, please visit their website: https://bigbuddiesofbloomfield.squarespace.com/

Two BHHS 9th graders were recently inspired to coordinate a book drive to benefit Brilliant Detroit. “While we are stuck at home in quarantine, I am finding myself not being as helpful to the community as I usually am I found out that Brilliant Detroit was looking for books. I thought, what a better idea than to help Brilliant Detroit for the second year in a row? I then reached out to Brooke Bugajewski and together we started this amazing book drive,” shares BHHS 9th grader Cameron Klein.

Prior knowledge and experience with Brilliant Detroit led Klein to want to reach out and help the organization again. Bugajewski adds, “I love to help out in the community, and it's really hard to do that right now. Cameron and I both really enjoy reading, and understand that many kids don't have books. Especially now, we want all kids to have something to do when stuck inside.”

Learn more: http://ow.ly/GWij50zE8W4

Did you know William Shakespeare's birthday is celebrated on April 23? No birth records exist, but an old church record indicates that a William Shakespeare was baptized at Holy Trinity Church in Stratford-upon-Avon on April 26, 1564. From this, it is believed he was born on or near April 23, 1564.

Fast-forward to 2019, and Bloomfield Hills High School performed Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

#TBT

Why Read 20 Minutes a Day? Reading is "brain food"!

Our brains develop as we "feed" them with experiences. The experience of reading (whether you're the reader or the one being read to) activates and "exercises" many of the areas of the brain!

The visual cortex works as your eyes track the words on the page and look at the illustrations. Your memory makes connections between what you already know about the topic of the story and its content. You integrate new information learned through reading further strengthening and growing your network of knowledge.

Reading provides one of the most enriching and complex brain activities available in life! #TidbitTuesday

Learn More: https://www.k12reader.com/why-read-20-minutes-a-day/

The Traveling Mural Project connected over 400 schools around the world to create murals of peace, friendship, diversity, and love - including Lone Pine and Way!

Last spring, Lone Pine Media Specialist Denise Brandt reached out to the other Bloomfield Hills elementary art teachers and media specialists with a collaborative project idea. Brandt explains, “It was a wonderful opportunity for the elementary school librarians and art teachers to collaborate together to create a fun project for our students. Since we had so much fun on a smaller scale as a district last spring, we were excited to participate in the global event.”

Learn more: https://www.bloomfield.org/news/details/~board/lone-pine-news/post/traveling-mural-project
